nexttext:
Now, let $(E_n)_{n \geq 0}$ be a level-wise fibrant replacement of $\Sigma^{\infty}\mathscr{X}$, i.e., $E_n$ is a fibrant replacement of $\Sigma^n \mathscr{X}$ and let $E$ be a fibrant replacement of $\Sigma^{\infty} \mathscr{X}$.  By \cite[Corollary 2.16]{DundasRondigsOstvaer}, we conclude that filtered colimits in ${\mathrm{Spc}}_{k,\bullet}$ preserve fibrant objects.  From that observation, it follows that there is a simplicial weak equivalence of the form $\Omega^{\infty} E \cong {\operatorname{colim}}_{n} \Omega^n E_n$.

Now, if $\mathscr{F}$ is a pointed fibrant space, then there is an identification of {\em unpointed} mapping spaces ${\mathrm{Map}}(U,\mathscr{F}) = {\mathcal F}(U)$.  Thus, we conclude that there is an identification of pointed mapping spaces ${\mathrm{Map}}(U_+,{\mathcal F}) = {\mathcal F}(U)$ as well.  Since $U_+$ is $\omega$-compact in ${\mathrm{Spc}}_{k,\bullet}$ we conclude that ${\mathrm{Map}}(U_+,{\operatorname{colim}}_n \Omega^n E_n) \cong {\operatorname{colim}}_n {\mathrm{Map}}(U_+,\Omega^n E_n)$.  Combining this fact with the evident adjunctions, we see that there are a sequence of homotopy equivalences of Kan complexes of the form

nexttext:
If $Y$ is a pointed smooth scheme, then ${\operatorname{Sing}^{{{\mathbb A}^1}}\!\!} Y$ is defined by the assignment $R \mapsto {\operatorname{Sing}^{{{\mathbb A}^1}}\!\!} Y(R) = Y(\Delta^{\bullet}_R)$ \cite[p. 87]{MV}.  There is an associated functor from the category of rings to the category of pointed sets sending a ring $R$ to the set of connected components $\pi_0({\operatorname{Sing}^{{{\mathbb A}^1}}\!\!} Y(R))$ pointed by the image of the base point.  The following result connects the set of naive homotopy classes of maps to ``true" ${{\mathbb A}^1}$-homotopy classes of maps as studied in the previous section; these results allow us to interpret the cohomotopy groups above in ``concrete" terms.

\begin{thm}[{\cite[Theorems 4.2.1 and 4.2.2.]{AsokHoyoisWendtII}}]
\label{thm:naivevsrefined}
Assume $k$ is a field, $X = {\operatorname{Spec}} R$ is a smooth affine $k$-scheme and $n \geq 0$ is an integer; if $n$ is even and $\geq 6$ assume further that $k$ is infinite and has characteristic different from $2$.  The map
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex18.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Delta^{n}_{R}:={\operatorname{Spec}}R[t_{0},\ldots,t_{n}]/(\sum_{i}t_{i}=1)." display="block"><mrow><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>n</mi></msubsup><mo>:=</mo><mo>Spec</mo><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>/</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>i</mi></munder><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

the morphisms $\phi$ and $\nabla$ in this diagram are described in Lemmas~\ref{lem:modelforwedgesum} and \ref{lem:geometricfold} (and the intervening discussion).

We now describe the map labelled $\exists$.  Suppose $f$ and $g$ are such that $f^{-1}(Z_n)$ and $g^{-1}(Z_n)$ are disjoint, which we can assume by Lemma~\ref{lem:generalpositionmaps}. In that case, we know that $(f \times g) \circ \Delta$ lifts, up to naive ${{\mathbb A}^1}$-homotopy, to a morphism $h: U \to (Q_{2n} \times Q_{2n}) \setminus (Z_n \times Z_n)$.

Next, note that the map ${\operatorname{Sing}^{{{\mathbb A}^1}}\!\!} \widetilde{Q_{2n} \vee Q_{2n}} \to {\operatorname{Sing}^{{{\mathbb A}^1}}\!\!} (Q_{2n} \times Q_{2n}) \setminus (Z_n \times Z_n)$ induced by $\phi$ is a Zariski fiber space with affine space fibers by construction; therefore by appeal to \cite[Lemma 4.2.4]{AsokHoyoisWendtII} we conclude that it is a weak equivalence when evaluated on any smooth affine $k$-scheme.  Thus, for any smooth affine $k$-scheme $U$ the induced map $\pi_0({\operatorname{Sing}^{{{\mathbb A}^1}}\!\!} \widetilde{Q_{2n} \vee Q_{2n}}(U)) \to \pi_0({\operatorname{Sing}^{{{\mathbb A}^1}}\!\!} (Q_{2n} \times Q_{2n}) \setminus (Z_n \times Z_n)(U))$ is a bijection, i.e., any morphism of $k$-schemes $h: U \to (Q_{2n} \times Q_{2n}) \setminus (Z_n \times Z_n)$ lifts uniquely up to naive ${{\mathbb A}^1}$-homotopy to a morphism of $k$-schemes $\tilde{h}: U \to \widetilde{Q_{2n} \vee Q_{2n}}$.

Furthermore, we can write down an ``explicit" formula for the map $\tilde{h}$, at least up to naive ${{\mathbb A}^1}$-homotopy.  Let $\varphi:k[x,y,z]/(xy=z(1-z))\to k[U]$ and $\psi:k[x,y,z]/(xy=z(1-z))\to k[U]$ be the maps corresponding to $f$ and $g$.  We write down a ring map from the coordinate ring displayed in Example~\ref{ex:explicitjouanolou} to $k[U]$.  The images of the variables $(x,y,z,x^\prime,y^\prime,z^\prime)$ are determined by $\varphi$ and $\psi$. By assumption, we know that the ideals $I:=\langle \varphi(x),\varphi(z)\rangle$ and $I^\prime:= \langle \psi(x^\prime),\psi(z^\prime)\rangle$ are comaximal. Therefore we can find $n+1$-tuples $(a,a_{n+1})$ (where, as above $a = (a_1,\ldots,a_n)$) and $(b,b_{n+1})$ such that

U \ar@{-->}[uurr]^{\exists}\ar[r]^{\Delta}& U \times U \ar[r]^{f \times g} & Q_{2n} \times Q_{2n} &
}
\]

the morphisms $\phi$ and $\nabla$ in this diagram are described in Lemmas~\ref{lem:modelforwedgesum} and \ref{lem:geometricfold} (and the intervening discussion).

We now describe the map labelled $\exists$.  Suppose $f$ and $g$ are such that $f^{-1}(Z_n)$ and $g^{-1}(Z_n)$ are disjoint, which we can assume by Lemma~\ref{lem:generalpositionmaps}. In that case, we know that $(f \times g) \circ \Delta$ lifts, up to naive ${{\mathbb A}^1}$-homotopy, to a morphism $h: U \to (Q_{2n} \times Q_{2n}) \setminus (Z_n \times Z_n)$.

Next, note that the map ${\operatorname{Sing}^{{{\mathbb A}^1}}\!\!} \widetilde{Q_{2n} \vee Q_{2n}} \to {\operatorname{Sing}^{{{\mathbb A}^1}}\!\!} (Q_{2n} \times Q_{2n}) \setminus (Z_n \times Z_n)$ induced by $\phi$ is a Zariski fiber space with affine space fibers by construction; therefore by appeal to \cite[Lemma 4.2.4]{AsokHoyoisWendtII} we conclude that it is a weak equivalence when evaluated on any smooth affine $k$-scheme.  Thus, for any smooth affine $k$-scheme $U$ the induced map $\pi_0({\operatorname{Sing}^{{{\mathbb A}^1}}\!\!} \widetilde{Q_{2n} \vee Q_{2n}}(U)) \to \pi_0({\operatorname{Sing}^{{{\mathbb A}^1}}\!\!} (Q_{2n} \times Q_{2n}) \setminus (Z_n \times Z_n)(U))$ is a bijection, i.e., any morphism of $k$-schemes $h: U \to (Q_{2n} \times Q_{2n}) \setminus (Z_n \times Z_n)$ lifts uniquely up to naive ${{\mathbb A}^1}$-homotopy to a morphism of $k$-schemes $\tilde{h}: U \to \widetilde{Q_{2n} \vee Q_{2n}}$.

Furthermore, we can write down an ``explicit" formula for the map $\tilde{h}$, at least up to naive ${{\mathbb A}^1}$-homotopy.  Let $\varphi:k[x,y,z]/(xy=z(1-z))\to k[U]$ and $\psi:k[x,y,z]/(xy=z(1-z))\to k[U]$ be the maps corresponding to $f$ and $g$.  We write down a ring map from the coordinate ring displayed in Example~\ref{ex:explicitjouanolou} to $k[U]$.  The images of the variables $(x,y,z,x^\prime,y^\prime,z^\prime)$ are determined by $\varphi$ and $\psi$. By assumption, we know that the ideals $I:=\langle \varphi(x),\varphi(z)\rangle$ and $I^\prime:= \langle \psi(x^\prime),\psi(z^\prime)\rangle$ are comaximal. Therefore we can find $n+1$-tuples $(a,a_{n+1})$ (where, as above $a = (a_1,\ldots,a_n)$) and $(b,b_{n+1})$ such that

nexttext: Using Lemma~\ref{lem:movingeuler}, we see that there exists an ideal $K$ of height $\geq n$ which is comaximal with $I_1^2$. Moreover, we have $\mathrm{ht}((K+I_i)/I_i)\geq n$ for any $i=2,\ldots,r$ and $\mathrm{ht}((K+J_j)/J_j)\geq n$ for any $j=1,\ldots,m$. As the ideals $I_2,\ldots,I_n,J_1,\ldots,J_m$ are of height $n$ and $R$ is of dimension $2n-1$, we obtain that $K$ is pairwise comaximal with all of them. Moreover, the surjective homomorphism $f:R^n\to I\cap K$ yields a surjective homomorphism $\omega_K:R^n\to K/K^2$ and we have $(I,\omega_I)+(K,\omega_K)=0$ in $E^n(R)$. It follows that

prevtext: where the map $Um_{d+1}(R)/E_{d+1}(R)\to \mathrm{E}^d(R)$ is defined as follows.  One first defines the map $\phi$ on ``special" unimodular rows: suppose $(a_1,\ldots,a_{d+1})$ is a unimodular row such that the ideal $I:=\langle a_1,\ldots,a_d\rangle$ has height $d$.  In this case, observe that $a_{d+1}$ is a unit modulo $I$ and define $\omega_I:(R/I)^d\to I/I^2$ by sending $e_i\mapsto \overline a_i$.  Then set
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex46.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\phi(a_{1},\ldots,a_{d+1}):=(I,a_{d+1}\omega_{I})." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>ϕ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>:=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>I</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>I</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>
